fields.descriptive_line: Theatrical ensemble of cape, doublet, round hose and shoes worn by Sir Henry Irving as Malvolio in Twelth Night, at the Lyceum in 1884, under his own management.
fields.physical_description:
[cape] Short cape of black felt, braided in grey, grey lining, standing short collar, buttoning to both shoulders.
[doublet] Doublet, 17th century style, fitted, black satin with vertical yellow piping, standing collar, small shoulder-wings, gold coloured buttons on cuff.
[breeches] Breeches, 17th century style, round hose with attached canions to knee, black satin, puffed with vertical yellow piping, metallic buttons at knee.
[shoe] One of a pair of taupe buckle shoes, black grosgrain edge. The buckle is missing. There are two straps across the instep, one longer than the other. The longer strap has 6 holes, four of which have been oversewn in black thread, seemingly for decorative effect as there is there is no evidence that they were used. Small heel.
[shoe] Right shoe, from a pair of taupe buckle shoes, black grosgrain edge. The buckle is missing. There are two straps across the instep, one longer than the other. The longer strap has 6 holes, four of which have been oversewn in black thread, seemingly for decorative effect as there is there is no evidence that they were used. Small heel.
fields.dimensions:
[cape] Length: 57 cm, Circumference: 187 cm measured at bottom hem, Width: 86 cm maximum width flat
[doublet] Length: 74 cm, Width: 58 cm maximum width across shoulders
[breeches] Length: 83 cm, Width: 42 cm measured at waist
[shoe] Length: 31.5 cm of 'foot', Height: 2.25 cm heel, Height: 10.5 cm from base of sole to top of upper
[shoe] Length: 31 cm of 'foot', Height: 2 cm Heel, Height: 10.5 cm from base of sole to top of upper
fields.public_access_description:
This costume was worn by the actor Henry Irving (1838-1905) when playing the role of Malvolio in the 1884 production of Twelfth Night by William Shakespeare. 

Twelfth Night was not popular among Victorian audiences and the play's chances of success were not improved by the heat wave which greeted the first performances. Further disaster struck when blood poisoning compelled Ellen Terry (1847-1928) to leave the production after only sixteen performances, and her sister Marion Terry (1853-1930) had to take over the role of Viola. 

Audiences were also dismayed by Irving’s decision to play Malvolio as a figure who was far more tragic than comic, and some actually booed at the end. Irving retaliated with a furious curtain speech which Ellen described as 'the only mistake I ever saw him make'. Unsurprisingly the production ran for only thirty nine performances in London and was never revived. Despite the failure of the London production Irving decided to assemble a new cast to mount a production of the play on the subsequent tour to America and this revised version was received much more positively by American audiences.

Henry Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learnt his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  In 1871 he joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman.  Irving remained at the Lyceum until 1902, taking over the management of the theatre in 1878, thereby achieving the status of an "actor-manager".  At the Lyceum, Irving produced a range of plays both old and new, including melodrama, Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  He worked tirelessly to raise the status of the Theatre profession both in the view of the public and among official bodies, especially religious organisations.  His success in this field was recognised in 1895, when he became the first actor to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Many of Irving's productions were spectacularly staged with large casts of performers.  He created desired effects of colour and movement using scenery, costume and lighting, set to music appropriate to the action, played by a full orchestra.  Although from the 1880s electric lighting was available for theatres, Irving always used gas, as well as lime-light (a form of spot-lighting).  Gas lighting gave a softer appearance to the general stage picture, whilst lime-light could be used to highlight Irving as the focus of attention at key points in the play.  Outside of London, Irving toured complete productions, taking the full London company, scenery and costumes, throughout the United Kingdom and also across the United States and Canada.  His was the first generation that could do this through the rapid development of the railway system.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 107.
